canonical_explanation.text: An ecosystem is a self-sustaining system of living organisms (biotic components) interacting with the non-living environment (abiotic components). Biotic components include producers (green plants that make food through photosynthesis), consumers (herbivores, carnivores, omnivores), and decomposers (bacteria, fungi that break down dead matter). Energy flows through an ecosystem via food chains and food webs. At each trophic level, only 10% of the energy is transferred to the next level (10% law). Biological magnification refers to the increase in concentration of non-biodegradable substances (like pesticides) at each trophic level. The ozone layer protects life on Earth from harmful ultraviolet radiation. Ozone depletion, primarily caused by chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), leads to increased UV radiation reaching Earth. Waste can be biodegradable (broken down by natural processes) or non-biodegradable (persists in the environment).
rules: Ecosystem = Biotic components (producers, consumers, decomposers) + Abiotic components (sunlight, water, soil, air, temperature).
Food chain: linear pathway showing energy flow from producer to top consumer.
Food web: interconnected network of multiple food chains in an ecosystem.
10% Law: Only 10% of energy is transferred from one trophic level to the next.
Biological magnification: concentration of non-biodegradable substances increases at higher trophic levels.
Ozone (O₃) is formed in the stratosphere and protects against UV radiation.
CFCs (chlorofluorocarbons) are the primary cause of ozone layer depletion.
Biodegradable waste: broken down by microorganisms; Non-biodegradable: persists in environment.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an abiotic component of an ecosystem?
questions.explanation_correct: Sunlight is an abiotic (non-living) component of an ecosystem. Abiotic components include physical and chemical factors such as sunlight, temperature, water, soil, minerals, and air that influence the living organisms in the ecosystem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plants, animals, and bacteria are all biotic (living) components. Sunlight is a non-living (abiotic) factor that provides energy for photosynthesis and influences the entire ecosystem.

questions.question_text: Organisms that make their own food through photosynthesis are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Producers (also called autotrophs) are organisms that make their own food through photosynthesis using sunlight, carbon dioxide, and water. Green plants, algae, and some bacteria are producers. They form the first trophic level in any food chain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Consumers obtain food by eating other organisms. Decomposers break down dead matter. Scavengers feed on dead animals. Producers are organisms that synthesise their own food through photosynthesis.

questions.question_text: Decomposers in an ecosystem include:
questions.explanation_correct: Decomposers are organisms like bacteria and fungi that break down dead organic matter (dead plants, animals, and their waste products) into simpler inorganic substances. They play a vital role in nutrient recycling, returning nutrients to the soil for use by producers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Green plants are producers. Herbivores and carnivores are consumers. Only bacteria and fungi are the primary decomposers that break down dead organic matter and recycle nutrients.

questions.question_text: In a food chain, the first trophic level is always occupied by:
questions.explanation_correct: The first trophic level in any food chain is always occupied by producers (green plants or algae). They capture solar energy through photosynthesis and convert it into chemical energy (food). This energy then flows to consumers at higher trophic levels.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Herbivores occupy the second trophic level (primary consumers). Carnivores occupy the third level or higher. Decomposers act on all levels. Producers always form the base of every food chain at the first trophic level.

questions.question_text: According to the 10% law of energy transfer, if producers have 10,000 J of energy, how much energy is available to primary consumers?
questions.explanation_correct: According to the 10% law (proposed by Lindeman), only 10% of the energy at one trophic level is transferred to the next trophic level. If producers have 10,000 J, primary consumers will receive 10% = 1,000 J. The rest is used in life processes or lost as heat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Energy is not fully transferred between trophic levels. At each level, 90% is used for life processes or lost as heat. Only 10% of 10,000 J = 1,000 J is available to primary consumers.

questions.question_text: Which gas is responsible for the depletion of the ozone layer?
questions.explanation_correct: Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), used in refrigerators, air conditioners, and aerosol sprays, are the primary cause of ozone depletion. When CFCs reach the stratosphere, UV radiation breaks them down, releasing chlorine atoms that catalytically destroy ozone molecules.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbon dioxide contributes to global warming, not ozone depletion. Oxygen and nitrogen do not deplete the ozone layer. CFCs are specifically responsible for breaking down ozone in the stratosphere.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a biodegradable substance?
questions.explanation_correct: Vegetable peels are biodegradable — they can be broken down by microorganisms (bacteria and fungi) into simpler, harmless substances and are reintegrated into the environment through natural processes like composting.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic bags, aluminium cans, and glass bottles are non-biodegradable — they cannot be easily broken down by microorganisms and persist in the environment for hundreds of years. Only vegetable peels are naturally biodegradable.

questions.question_text: A food web is:

options.text: A network of interconnected food chains

questions.explanation_correct: A food web is a network of interconnected food chains in an ecosystem. It shows the complex feeding relationships among organisms, where one organism may be part of multiple food chains. Food webs give a more realistic picture of energy flow than individual food chains.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A food web is not a single chain but a complex network of many interconnected food chains. It is not a spider web or a pyramid. It represents the multiple feeding relationships that exist in any real ecosystem.

questions.question_text: An organism that feeds on both plants and animals is called a/an:
questions.explanation_correct: An omnivore is an organism that feeds on both plants and animals. Examples include humans, bears, crows, and cockroaches. They occupy multiple trophic levels in food chains because they can act as both primary and secondary consumers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Herbivores eat only plants. Carnivores eat only animals. Decomposers break down dead matter. Omnivores eat both plants and animals, giving them a more flexible diet.

questions.question_text: The ozone layer is found in which layer of the atmosphere?
questions.explanation_correct: The ozone layer is located in the stratosphere, approximately 15-35 km above the Earth's surface. Ozone (O₃) molecules in this layer absorb harmful ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun, protecting life on Earth from its damaging effects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The troposphere is the lowest layer where weather occurs. The mesosphere and thermosphere are higher layers. The ozone layer is specifically located in the stratosphere.

questions.question_text: In the food chain: Grass → Grasshopper → Frog → Snake → Eagle, which organism is the tertiary consumer?
questions.explanation_correct: In this food chain: Grass (producer, T1) → Grasshopper (primary consumer, T2) → Frog (secondary consumer, T3) → Snake (tertiary consumer, T4) → Eagle (quaternary consumer, T5). The snake is the tertiary consumer at the fourth trophic level.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Grasshopper is the primary consumer (eats plants). Frog is the secondary consumer (eats primary consumer). Eagle is the quaternary consumer. Snake, which eats the secondary consumer (frog), is the tertiary consumer.

questions.question_text: Energy flows in one direction through a food chain — from producers to consumers.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Energy flows in a unidirectional manner through a food chain — from the sun to producers, then to primary consumers, secondary consumers, and so on. Energy cannot flow backward in a food chain. At each level, energy is lost as heat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Energy flow in an ecosystem is always unidirectional: Sun → Producers → Primary consumers → Secondary consumers → Tertiary consumers. It does not cycle back like nutrients do.

questions.question_text: Plastic is a biodegradable material that can be easily broken down by bacteria.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Plastic is a non-biodegradable material that cannot be easily broken down by bacteria or other decomposers. It persists in the environment for hundreds to thousands of years, causing pollution in soil, water bodies, and harming wildlife.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic is non-biodegradable. Microorganisms cannot decompose it easily. It accumulates in the environment and can take 500-1000 years to degrade. This is why plastic pollution is a major environmental concern.

questions.question_text: Decomposers play an important role in recycling nutrients back into the ecosystem.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Decomposers (bacteria and fungi) break down dead organic matter into simpler inorganic substances like carbon dioxide, water, and mineral nutrients. These nutrients are returned to the soil and atmosphere, making them available for producers to use again. Without decomposers, nutrients would remain locked in dead matter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Decomposers are essential for nutrient cycling in ecosystems. They convert complex organic matter into simpler forms that can be reused by plants, completing the nutrient cycle.

questions.question_text: According to the 10% law, only ___% of energy is transferred from one trophic level to the next.
questions.explanation_correct: The 10% law (Lindeman's trophic efficiency) states that only about 10% of the energy at one trophic level is passed on to the next level. The remaining 90% is used for the organism's own life processes (respiration, movement, growth) or is lost as heat to the environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is '10'. This means that for every 1000 J of energy at the producer level, only 100 J reaches primary consumers, 10 J reaches secondary consumers, and 1 J reaches tertiary consumers.

questions.question_text: The increase in concentration of harmful chemicals at each trophic level is called biological ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Biological magnification (or biomagnification) is the progressive increase in the concentration of non-biodegradable toxic substances (such as DDT, mercury) at each successive trophic level in a food chain. Top predators accumulate the highest concentrations of these chemicals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'magnification'. Biological magnification occurs because non-biodegradable substances cannot be metabolised or excreted. They accumulate in the body fat of organisms and become more concentrated at higher trophic levels.

questions.question_text: Animals that eat only plants are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Herbivores are animals that feed exclusively on plants or plant products. They are primary consumers in a food chain, occupying the second trophic level. Examples include deer, cows, rabbits, caterpillars, and grasshoppers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'herbivores'. They are the first level of consumers in any food chain, directly feeding on producers (plants). Carnivores eat animals, and omnivores eat both.

questions.question_text: The ozone molecule is made up of ___ oxygen atoms.
questions.explanation_correct: Ozone (O₃) is a molecule made up of three oxygen atoms. It is formed in the stratosphere when UV radiation breaks an oxygen molecule (O₂) into two oxygen atoms, one of which then combines with another O₂ molecule to form O₃. This ozone shields Earth from harmful UV radiation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'three'. While normal oxygen gas has two atoms (O₂), ozone has three atoms (O₃). This extra oxygen atom makes ozone highly reactive and effective at absorbing UV radiation.

questions.question_text: The maximum number of trophic levels in a food chain is typically four or five.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Food chains typically have 3-5 trophic levels because the 10% law limits the amount of energy available at higher levels. After 4-5 transfers, the energy remaining is too little to sustain another trophic level. This is why top predators are relatively rare in any ecosystem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Due to the loss of energy (90%) at each trophic level, food chains rarely have more than 4-5 levels. There simply isn't enough energy to support more levels.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a biotic component of an ecosystem?
questions.explanation_correct: Temperature is an abiotic (non-living) component of an ecosystem. It influences the types of organisms that can survive in an environment. Trees, insects, and fungi are all biotic (living) components that interact with each other and the abiotic environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Trees (producers), insects (consumers), and fungi (decomposers) are all living components. Temperature is a non-living physical factor (abiotic component) that affects the ecosystem but is not alive itself.

questions.question_text: If producers in an ecosystem capture 10,000 J of energy, how much energy would be available to the secondary consumers?
questions.explanation_correct: Applying the 10% law: Producers (10,000 J) → Primary consumers receive 10% = 1,000 J → Secondary consumers receive 10% of 1,000 J = 100 J. So only 100 J of the original 10,000 J would be available to secondary consumers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1,000 J is available to primary consumers (not secondary). 10 J would be for tertiary consumers. Using the 10% law twice: 10,000 → 1,000 → 100 J for secondary consumers.

questions.question_text: DDT was sprayed on crops to kill pests. Later, high concentrations of DDT were found in fish-eating birds. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: This is biological magnification. DDT is non-biodegradable, so it is not broken down and accumulates in the bodies of organisms. As it passes through the food chain (crops → insects → fish → birds), its concentration increases at each trophic level, resulting in very high levels in top predators like fish-eating birds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While a food chain is involved, the specific phenomenon of increasing DDT concentration at higher trophic levels is called biological magnification. It is not biodegradation (DDT cannot be decomposed) or decomposition.

questions.question_text: If all decomposers were removed from an ecosystem, what would happen?

options.text: Dead organic matter would accumulate and nutrients would not be recycled
More food would be available for consumers

questions.explanation_correct: Without decomposers, dead plants, animals, and waste would accumulate since no organism would break them down. Nutrients locked in dead matter would not be recycled back to the soil, eventually depleting the soil of essential minerals. Producers would not get nutrients to grow, leading to the collapse of the ecosystem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Removing decomposers would dramatically affect the ecosystem. Dead matter would pile up, nutrients would not be recycled, soil fertility would decline, and eventually the entire ecosystem would collapse.

questions.question_text: Why do food chains generally have only 3-5 trophic levels?

options.text: Because there are not enough species
Because only 10% energy transfers at each level, leaving too little energy beyond 4-5 levels
Because the environment cannot support more levels

questions.explanation_correct: Due to the 10% law, at each trophic level, 90% of energy is lost. Starting with 10,000 J: T1=10,000 → T2=1,000 → T3=100 → T4=10 → T5=1 J. After 4-5 levels, the energy available is too small to sustain another level of consumers. This is why food chains are limited in length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The number of species is not the limiting factor. Top predators do not eat everything. The key limiting factor is energy — the progressive loss of 90% energy at each level means very little energy remains after 4-5 transfers.

questions.question_text: Why is it recommended to use paper bags instead of plastic bags?

options.text: Paper bags are biodegradable while plastic bags are non-biodegradable and pollute the environment

questions.explanation_correct: Paper bags are recommended because they are biodegradable — bacteria and fungi can decompose them naturally within weeks. Plastic bags are non-biodegradable and persist in the environment for hundreds of years, causing soil pollution, water pollution, clogging drains, and harming wildlife that ingests them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cost, strength, and appearance are not the primary reasons. The environmental reason is key: paper decomposes naturally while plastic persists indefinitely, causing severe pollution and ecological damage.

questions.question_text: In a pond ecosystem, which organisms would be the producers?
questions.explanation_correct: In a pond ecosystem, the producers are phytoplankton (microscopic floating plants) and aquatic plants (like water lilies, hydrilla). They perform photosynthesis using sunlight to produce food, forming the base of the aquatic food chain. Fish, frogs, and insects are consumers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fish are consumers (herbivorous or carnivorous). Frogs are secondary consumers. Insects can be primary or secondary consumers. Phytoplankton and aquatic plants are the producers that make food through photosynthesis.

questions.question_text: A farmer notices that birds eating fish from his pond are dying, even though the pesticide was sprayed on nearby crops, not in the pond. The most likely explanation is:

options.text: The birds are allergic to fish
Biological magnification — pesticide concentrated through the food chain
The birds ate poisoned crops directly

questions.explanation_correct: This is biological magnification. The pesticide washed from crops into the pond water, was absorbed by aquatic plants, then concentrated in small fish, and further concentrated in larger fish. Birds eating these fish received a very high dose of the pesticide due to its accumulation through the food chain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Birds are not allergic to fish. They did not eat crops directly. The fish are not naturally toxic. The pesticide entered the aquatic food chain and became increasingly concentrated at each trophic level through biological magnification.

questions.question_text: Why is a food web considered more realistic than a single food chain?

options.text: Because most organisms feed on multiple species, creating interconnected chains
Because food chains do not exist in nature
Because food webs have fewer organisms

questions.explanation_correct: A food web is more realistic because in any ecosystem, organisms rarely feed on just one species. A rabbit might eat different types of grass and plants, and it might be eaten by foxes, hawks, or snakes. These multiple feeding relationships create a complex network of interconnected food chains — a food web.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Food webs are more complex, not simpler. Food chains do exist but are oversimplified. Food webs have more organisms and connections. The key reason is that organisms have multiple feeding relationships that cannot be shown by a single linear food chain.

questions.question_text: What are the harmful effects of ozone depletion on living organisms?

options.text: Increased UV radiation reaching Earth, causing skin cancer, cataracts, and damage to plants
It increases oxygen in the atmosphere
It has no effect on living organisms

questions.explanation_correct: Ozone depletion allows more ultraviolet (UV-B) radiation to reach Earth's surface, which causes skin cancer (melanoma), cataracts (eye damage), weakened immune systems, reduced crop yields, damage to marine phytoplankton (affecting aquatic food chains), and accelerated ageing of skin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ozone depletion is different from global warming (though related). It does not increase oxygen. It significantly harms living organisms. The main effect is increased UV radiation, causing various health and ecological problems.

questions.question_text: Why are green plants called the 'foundation of life' in an ecosystem?

options.text: Because they are the tallest organisms
Because they produce food and oxygen through photosynthesis, supporting all other life
Because they were the first organisms on Earth

questions.explanation_correct: Green plants are the foundation of life because they are producers — they convert solar energy into chemical energy (food) through photosynthesis, which is then available to all consumers. They also produce oxygen needed for respiration by most organisms. Without producers, no ecosystem could function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Height, historical origin, and shade are not the reasons. Plants are fundamental because they produce the food and oxygen upon which all other organisms in the ecosystem depend.

questions.question_text: Biological magnification causes the highest concentration of harmful chemicals to be found in organisms at the top of the food chain.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. In biological magnification, non-biodegradable chemicals like DDT accumulate and become more concentrated at each successive trophic level. Top predators (like eagles, sharks, or humans) accumulate the highest concentrations because they consume organisms that have already accumulated the chemicals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Each organism at a higher trophic level consumes many organisms from the level below, accumulating their stored chemicals. This results in the highest concentration at the top of the food chain.

questions.question_text: The two main components of an ecosystem are ___ (living) and abiotic (non-living) components.
questions.explanation_correct: Biotic components are the living parts of an ecosystem, including all organisms — producers (plants), consumers (animals), and decomposers (bacteria, fungi). Together with abiotic (non-living) components like sunlight, water, temperature, and soil, they form a complete, functioning ecosystem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'biotic'. Biotic means relating to living organisms. An ecosystem consists of biotic (all living organisms and their interactions) and abiotic (all non-living physical and chemical factors) components.

questions.question_text: In an ecosystem, the different levels of a food chain through which energy flows are called ___ levels.
questions.explanation_correct: Trophic levels represent the position of an organism in a food chain. The first trophic level consists of producers, the second of primary consumers (herbivores), the third of secondary consumers (small carnivores), and so on. Energy decreases with each successive trophic level.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'trophic'. The word 'trophic' comes from the Greek word 'trophe' meaning nourishment. Trophic levels represent feeding positions in an ecosystem.

questions.question_text: Substances that cannot be broken down by biological processes and persist in the environment are called ___ substances.
questions.explanation_correct: Non-biodegradable substances cannot be decomposed by microorganisms and persist in the environment for very long periods. Examples include plastics, DDT, heavy metals, glass, and synthetic materials. They cause pollution and can accumulate in food chains through biological magnification.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'non-biodegradable'. Unlike biodegradable substances (like paper, food waste) that decompose naturally, non-biodegradable materials accumulate in the environment and cause long-term pollution.

questions.question_text: What happens to the number of organisms at each successive trophic level in an ecosystem?
questions.explanation_correct: Generally, the number of organisms decreases at each successive trophic level. There are more producers than herbivores, more herbivores than carnivores, and so on. This is because less energy is available at each higher level to support organisms. This pattern is shown by the pyramid of numbers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The number of organisms does not increase or remain constant. There is a clear pattern: fewer organisms at higher trophic levels. This is directly related to the decreasing energy available at each successive level.

questions.question_text: Construct a possible food chain in a forest ecosystem and identify the trophic levels.

options.text: Deer → Grass → Tiger → Decomposer (T1: Deer, T2: Grass, T3: Tiger)
Grass (T1: Producer) → Deer (T2: Primary consumer) → Tiger (T3: Secondary consumer) → Decomposers
Tiger → Deer → Grass (T1: Tiger, T2: Deer, T3: Grass)

questions.explanation_correct: The correct food chain starts with the producer: Grass (T1: Producer, autotroph) → Deer (T2: Primary consumer, herbivore) → Tiger (T3: Secondary consumer, carnivore) → Decomposers break down dead matter. Energy flows from producers to consumers in a unidirectional manner.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Food chains always start with producers (plants), not consumers. Energy flows from lower to higher trophic levels. The correct order is: Producer → Primary consumer → Secondary consumer, with decomposers acting on dead matter at all levels.

questions.question_text: In a food chain, if the energy available at the producer level is 100,000 J, calculate the energy available to the organism at the fourth trophic level.
questions.explanation_correct: Using the 10% law: T1 (Producers) = 100,000 J → T2 (Primary consumers) = 10,000 J → T3 (Secondary consumers) = 1,000 J → T4 (Tertiary consumers) = 100 J. At the fourth trophic level, only 100 J of energy (0.1% of the original) is available.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Apply the 10% law three times: 100,000 × 0.1 = 10,000 (T2) × 0.1 = 1,000 (T3) × 0.1 = 100 (T4). The answer is 100 J at the fourth trophic level.

questions.question_text: Explain how the use of CFCs has led to the depletion of the ozone layer.

options.text: CFCs react with nitrogen to form acid rain
CFCs release chlorine in the stratosphere, which breaks down ozone molecules catalytically
CFCs block sunlight from reaching the ozone layer
CFCs convert ozone into oxygen directly

questions.explanation_correct: When CFCs (used in refrigerators and aerosols) rise to the stratosphere, UV radiation breaks them down, releasing chlorine atoms. Each chlorine atom acts as a catalyst, breaking ozone (O₃) into oxygen (O₂) and an oxygen atom. A single chlorine atom can destroy thousands of ozone molecules before being deactivated. This has created the 'ozone hole' over Antarctica.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CFCs do not react with nitrogen or block sunlight. They do not directly convert ozone to oxygen. The mechanism involves UV-induced release of chlorine atoms that catalytically destroy ozone molecules in the stratosphere.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Decomposers are essential for the sustainability of an ecosystem.
Reason: They recycle nutrients by breaking down dead organic matter into simpler substances.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation
Both are true, but reason is not the correct explanation
Assertion is true but reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion. Decomposers are essential because they break down dead organisms and waste into simpler inorganic nutrients that are returned to the soil. Plants (producers) then absorb these nutrients, completing the nutrient cycle. Without this recycling, nutrients would be permanently locked in dead matter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is correct — decomposers are essential. The reason is also correct — they recycle nutrients through decomposition. And the reason directly explains why they are essential — without nutrient recycling, ecosystems would collapse.

questions.question_text: Differentiate between biodegradable and non-biodegradable waste with examples.

options.text: Biodegradable: plastic, glass; Non-biodegradable: paper, food
Biodegradable: paper, food waste, cotton; Non-biodegradable: plastic, glass, metals
There is no difference between them
Biodegradable: all industrial waste; Non-biodegradable: all household waste

questions.explanation_correct: Biodegradable waste can be decomposed by microorganisms: paper, food waste, cotton, wood, dead leaves, cow dung. Non-biodegradable waste cannot be decomposed naturally and persists in the environment: plastic, glass, metals, synthetic fibres, DDT, radioactive waste. Proper segregation and disposal of both types is essential.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic and glass are non-biodegradable (not biodegradable). Paper and food are biodegradable (not non-biodegradable). There is a clear difference. The correct distinction is based on whether microorganisms can break down the substance.

questions.question_text: What would happen to a food web if all the producers were removed?

options.text: Consumers would find alternative food sources
The entire food web would collapse as all organisms depend directly or indirectly on producers
The food web would continue with just consumers and decomposers

questions.explanation_correct: If all producers were removed, the entire food web would collapse. Herbivores would starve first (no food source), then carnivores that eat herbivores would starve, and so on. All organisms in the ecosystem depend directly or indirectly on producers for food and energy. Without the base of the food web, no trophic level can survive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Consumers cannot find alternative food if all producers are gone — they are the ultimate source of all food. Not just herbivores would be affected — the entire chain collapses. The food web cannot function without producers.

questions.question_text: Why are non-biodegradable pesticides a greater environmental concern than biodegradable ones?

options.text: Because they persist in the environment, accumulate in food chains, and cause biological magnification

questions.explanation_correct: Non-biodegradable pesticides (like DDT) are a greater concern because: (1) they persist in the environment for decades, (2) they accumulate in the soil and water, (3) they enter food chains and undergo biological magnification, reaching harmful concentrations in top predators, and (4) they can cause chronic health effects in humans and wildlife.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cost, smell, and pest-killing ability are not the main concerns. The environmental hazard of non-biodegradable pesticides lies in their persistence, accumulation through food chains (biological magnification), and long-term toxic effects on ecosystems and human health.

questions.question_text: Draw a diagram showing the flow of energy in an ecosystem. Which of the following correctly represents this flow?

options.text: Sun → Producers → Primary consumers → Secondary consumers → Tertiary consumers (unidirectional, energy lost as heat at each level)

questions.explanation_correct: Energy flow in an ecosystem is unidirectional: Sun → Producers (photosynthesis captures solar energy) → Primary consumers → Secondary consumers → Tertiary consumers. At each level, about 90% of energy is lost as heat. Unlike nutrients, energy does not cycle — it flows in one direction and is eventually lost as heat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Energy flow is not circular — it does not return to the sun. It does not flow in reverse from consumers to producers. Decomposers release energy as heat during decomposition. Energy is unidirectional, flowing from sun through producers to consumers, with losses at each step.

questions.question_text: Why is there no more than 4 to 5 links in a food chain? Explain using the 10% law.

options.text: Because there are only 5 types of organisms
Because after 4-5 transfers at 10% each, the remaining energy (0.01-0.1% of original) is too little to sustain another trophic level
Because predators only eat organisms from one level
Because decomposers limit the chain to 5 levels

questions.explanation_correct: With the 10% law, if producers have 10,000 J: T2 = 1,000 J (10%), T3 = 100 J (1%), T4 = 10 J (0.1%), T5 = 1 J (0.01%). After 4-5 levels, only 0.01-0.1% of the original energy remains, which is insufficient to support another trophic level. This energetic constraint limits food chain length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The limitation is not due to species types, predator behaviour, or decomposer activity. It is purely an energy constraint: the 10% transfer rate means that after 4-5 steps, the remaining energy is too small to sustain additional organisms.

questions.question_text: What measures have been taken to protect the ozone layer?

options.text: Montreal Protocol — phasing out CFCs and replacing them with eco-friendly alternatives
Adding more ozone to the atmosphere artificially

questions.explanation_correct: The Montreal Protocol (1987) is an international agreement to phase out the production and use of ozone-depleting substances, primarily CFCs. Countries agreed to replace CFCs with ozone-friendly alternatives (like HFCs). This has been one of the most successful international environmental agreements, with the ozone hole showing signs of recovery.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Increasing CFC production would worsen the problem. Adding ozone artificially is not practical. Significant measures have been taken. The Montreal Protocol is the key international agreement that phased out CFCs to protect the ozone layer.

questions.question_text: Unlike energy, nutrients are recycled in an ecosystem through biogeochemical cycles.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. While energy flows unidirectionally (from sun through producers to consumers, lost as heat at each level), nutrients like carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus are recycled. They move from the non-living environment to living organisms and back through biogeochemical cycles, making them available for reuse.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Energy and nutrients behave differently in ecosystems. Energy flows in one direction and is lost as heat. Nutrients are recycled through decomposition and biogeochemical cycles, making them perpetually available.

questions.question_text: An ecosystem can function without producers but not without consumers.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false — it is the opposite. An ecosystem cannot function without producers because they form the base of all food chains by converting solar energy into food. Theoretically, an ecosystem could exist with only producers and decomposers (no consumers), as decomposers would recycle nutrients. But without producers, no other organism can survive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Producers are the most essential biotic component of an ecosystem. They provide energy and food for all other organisms. An ecosystem can potentially exist without consumers but never without producers.

questions.question_text: The international agreement signed in 1987 to protect the ozone layer by phasing out CFCs is the ___ Protocol.
questions.explanation_correct: The Montreal Protocol was signed in 1987 and has been ratified by nearly all countries. It set targets for phasing out the production and consumption of ozone-depleting substances, primarily CFCs. It is considered one of the most successful environmental treaties in history.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Montreal'. The Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer was signed in Montreal, Canada in 1987. It has been instrumental in reducing CFC emissions and allowing the ozone layer to begin recovering.

questions.question_text: A graphical representation showing the number, biomass, or energy at each trophic level is called an ecological ___.
questions.explanation_correct: An ecological pyramid is a graphical representation of the trophic structure of an ecosystem. There are three types: pyramid of numbers (number of organisms), pyramid of biomass (total weight of organisms), and pyramid of energy (energy at each level). The pyramid of energy is always upright because energy decreases at each successive level.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'pyramid'. Ecological pyramids show the relationship between different trophic levels. They are typically shaped like a pyramid because producers (at the base) have the most energy/biomass/numbers, which decreases at each higher level.

questions.question_text: In an ecosystem, organisms that feed on dead organic matter and break it down are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Decomposers are microorganisms (mainly bacteria and fungi) that feed on dead organic matter — dead plants, animals, and waste products. They secrete enzymes that break down complex organic compounds into simpler inorganic substances like CO₂, water, and minerals. This process returns nutrients to the soil, completing the nutrient cycle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'decomposers'. They are also called saprotrophs. Without decomposers, dead matter would accumulate, nutrients would be locked up, and the ecosystem would cease to function.
